title: Interlocking dovetail-sided box for small 1/2 oz. eyedroppers and 15mL e-juice bottles

description.text:
This is a little interlocking design I made to organize a collection of small homemade Sriracha eyedroppers. I was inspired by another design I saw recently on this site and decided to make my own to suit my purposes.  
I designed this as a "cheap" design I could use to calibrate my machine as well as be something I could print over and over, and not mind having too many extras.  
The interior hole is designed to be a bit wider than 1" in diameter, and 7/8" deep. The overall size is about 1"h X 1.41"w X 1.41"d. The dovetails I had to play with their size a bit to get them to go together easy enough. Using the settings I have on the instructions page, I was able to print these so they were flexible enough to snap apart without damaging the dovetails. I haven't experimented further, once i found some settings that worked well, I ran with it.  
Let me know what you think or if there's any other details you'd like.  
Thanks Cracky for the inspiration.  
Enjoy!

I printed the ones in the photos on a SeeMeCNC Rostock MAX v2 I put together from a kit. I used white PLA on all the ones in the photos, as well, I used MatterControl to act as the printing program. Here are the settings I used:
  • Nozzle: 0.35mm
  • Layer Thickness: 0.2mm
  • Perimeter #: 2
  • Top Surfaces: 4
  • Bottom Surfaces: 3
  • Infill: Lines, 10%
  • Nozzle Temp: 225C
  • Bed Temp: 60C
  • Print Speed: no more than 60mm/s (I've included my settings in teh files)
    • There's some more specific settings, but I didn't try to push the speed of my printer on this design. A single one with these settings takes about 45 minutes to complete.

description.text: Paint Mixer
This is a bracket and hinge for mounting DC42's PanelDue LCD Control Panel on the Reprap Ormerod.

You will need two M5 nuts and 180mm of M5 screwed rod.
I originally intended to bolt the hinge to DC42's case, however ended up using superglue which is more than adequate over the base area of the hinge.
Clean the holes with an M5 drill bit.
Press the M5 nuts into their recesses. i used a vice.
Attach bracket/panel to RHS of Z axis using two m4 pan head screws or cap screws and standard m4 channel nuts to suit z-axis extrusion.
insert the screwed rod and fit the clamping knob

description.text: A small scene I made for all of you to print and enjoy. http://youtu.be/o7_vpVNBeSI

I included an extra version of the "island" without the holes so you can choose where you want to place the accesories. There is also an alternative version of the lights for when you have trouble printing them in one piece. Everything can be printed without supports. You won't need any glue for assembly. I made (little) pins to connect everything on the "island" The shortest pins are those for the "road". The two lights just slide in, they have no pins. When connecting the wheels and axles, first connect the wheels to the axles, then to the car body. The shortest axle is the one for the rear. The axle assembly isn't in the video. This was a last minute change to make it completely support and glue free. I have printed everything at 100 microns. except for the model of the road and the island. Those I printed at 270microns, just to speed it up. You can print the island without infill. This is one of many scenes I'm working on. I wanted to share this with all of you to give me an idea what I could do better/different with the other ones. Feel free to tell me what you think and if your interested check out my instagram page. Its full of 3D printed stuff ! http://instagram.com/toonramakers/

As part of my home renovations, I need more electrical outlet cover plates. This thing covers nema 5-15 plugs. These are the standard "Duplex" electrical outlets found in most home in the US. The OpenScad has code to print up as many 'gangs' as you want. One Gang == one set of two plugs. A "Two Gang" would have a total of 4 plugs, "Three Gang" would have a total of 6 plugs, etc. This thing is not a strict derivative of, but similar to:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3342 It is also not a strict derivative, but additive to this thing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6588 UPDATE:
Spacing on the outlet sockets was slightly off

1) Edit the OpenScad file to suit your needs.
Change the following line specifically:
Duplex_Standard_ngang(2);
2) Print out the cover plate
3) Attach it to your outlet using the screw hole
4) Rejoice

description.text:
LA LOS ANGELES Necklace  
dimensions: 50x50x3 mm
I dimensioned an NES cable endcap for a friend, designed it in Tinkercad, and printed it on a Rep 2. He said it fit (my NES is long since dead.)

For files like this with thin-walled cylinders, I like to reduce shells to 1 and up infill to 100%. It prevents delamination between the inner and outer walls of a cylinder.  
It was initially printed with 2 shells. I have yet to slice it with 1 shell and 100%, however.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lgzYsSmWkuC This comb actually works and makes the "comb noise" when the tines are plucked (?) in sequence. Print at 1 shell and 100% infill to make tines without holes.

Print it with 1 shell and 100% infill at a thin layer height for the best results.  
If you go with a more coarse layer height, you'll need to use the bottom of the print as the leading edge of the comb in practice, because the plastic spurs will likely catch hair.

comments.text:
I got excellent results from this after making two small adjustments to my default Slic3r settings:
1) change extrusion width from my default 0.6 to 0.4.
2) set "avoid crossing perimeters"
I used two shells and 20% infill because I wanted the nifty grid pattern to shine through my translucent filament.

comments.text: I've been repeatedly trying to print this in ABS and in PLA on a Prusa I3 with no luck. The ends of the tines always seem to want to lift up at some point during the print, causing the print to fail. I've been using painter's tape with hairspray when printing in PLA and using gluestick+ABS juice for ABS. Even had lifting when printing with a raft! I've tried a variety of bed temperatures and print speeds. I generally haven't had lifting/adhesion issues with printing other objects.

remixed_from.author: Folker
remixed_from.title: Laser cut Raspberry pi case yin yang / ying yang

description.text: Case for the brandnew RASPBERRYPI-2-MODB-1GB an the RASPBERRY PI B+. Ist auch fertig zu bekommen auf http://www.led-genial.de Montage-Video ist gerade in Arbeit - publiziere ich in Kürze. In diesem Gehäuse wird das Raspberry Pi durch die Spacer sauber fixiert. Es wackelt nichts und das Board sitzt fest, alle Buchsen sind somit exakt zugänglich. Außerdem gibt es keinen Bruch mehr mit den sonst üblichen Nasen. Die Seitenteile passen wie bei einem Puzzle nur in der richtigen Position zusammen. Man kann also nicht spiegelverkehrt montieren, was bei den meisten dieser Gehäuseart passieren kann. Für diese Teile ist unbedingt gewalztes Plexi zu benutzen. Hat den Nachteil, das gibt es nicht eingefärbt. Dafür kann man Gehäuseunterteil und Deckel (identisch) in GS (gegossen) fertigen. Dafür gibt‘s die tollsten Farben. Genau das war der Grund für die Entwicklung dieses Gehäuses. Leider hat die RaspPi Foundation nicht so gut nachgedacht. Die Montagebohrungen mögen einen runden imperialen Wert haben, sind aber für das metrische Europa mit 2,75 mm eine Winzigkeit unterdimensioniert. So kann man nur 2,5mm Gewinde benutzen. Die Teile sind leider erheblich teurer als die M3 Pendants. Einfache Gegenmaßnahme: aufbohren auf M3 - tut dem Board nichts.

comments.text:
Hi,
ich wollte die Befestigungslöcher nicht aufbohren, daher habe ich bei eBay ein 120-teiliges Sortiment mit M2-Distanzbolzen in verschiedenen Höhen für ca. 5EUR gekauft. Da ich auf die Unterseite ein mSATA-Laufwerk und auf die Oberseite ein Funkmodul für die Hausautomatisierung montiert habe, sind die verschiedenen Bolzenlängen für mich wirklich super.
Ist also relativ preiswert möglich.
Deine Vorlage musste ich dafür natürlich modifizieren. Das klappte aber mit Inkscape super, nachdem ich mehrere Layer eingefügt habe, in denen das Board und die Zusatzplatinchen sowie die Distanzbolzen eingezeichnet sind.
Super Arbeit, danke dafür!

remixed_from.author: random11
remixed_from.title: Master Ball, with magnetic clasp (Fixed Lid)

description.text:
The only thing I changed from the "Master Ball, with magnetic clasp" was the lid again.  
Print the Lid.stl file and print two copies of the Lid_Arch.stl file, they won't need supports. After printing the parts you should be able to easily assemble the lid. (Please note that the arches only fit in one way, so if it isn't fitting quite right flip it upside down) From there glue the button into the button holder. Then glue the button assembly and the ring to the bottom with the hinge in place as you glue the ring down. Then snap the hinge into the lid.  
You will need 2 magnets (1/4" X 1/16") and just glue them in place.  
Tip: Print your bottom piece at a higher in fill percentage, around 40-50% and then all the other parts at 5-10%. That way it will be bottom heavy and not roll around as much.

title: 5th Generation Replicator - Filament feed system for reduced feeding resistance

description.text:
UPDATE: An additional .stl file (5G+ Std Guide Tube.stl) has been added for 5th Gen owners with a Smart Extruder+ wanting a shorter filament feed path and less filament feed resistance. This type uses the standard filament guide tube which can be shortened by approx. 30% and will be a straighter feed path. No extruder cap fitting is required with this version. Just follow the filament drawer modifications. shorten the guide tube and your ready to go...
Please read the following overview / instructions: 
The filament feed system on the 5th Generation Replicator is not a free or smooth as on the earlier Replicator 2's. Having as little resistance along the feed route ensures the right amount of filament is delivered on demand and also that there is no resistance that could affect retraction. In addition, this may improve reliability and reduce wear within the Smart Extruder due to reducing the internal stresses caused through pulling filament into the Smart Extruder (i.e. may improve service life).     
This modification was developed to reduce the resistance along the 5th Generation filament feed route. (The route travels up from the spool then out of the filament drawer via a small hole followed by a fairly tight bend, along the back of the machine, through another bend then out through the front of the drawer before travelling through a considerable length of guide tubing before angling into the top of the Smart Extruder). In addition, the 5th Generation guide tube is considerably smaller so more restrictive than the tubing used on the earlier Replicator 2.   
After this modification is carried out the filament route will essentially be 'straight up and over' like on a Replicator 2. The tubing used is from a Replicator 2 (although a fraction longer Teflon tube would be better).  
The modification is relatively easy to carry of but does require drilling two holes in the drawer of a 5th Generation Replicator. Once drilled the printed parts can be installed in a matter of minutes along with a Replicator 2 guide tube (or similar) and use of 10mm cut from the original 5th Generation guide tube.

On a Replicator 2 the parts required for this modification were printed with Raft on, 4 shells and 50% infill at 0.20 (Std.) resolution. Printing on a 5th Generation Replicator should be similar. Additional requirements:
(1) A Replicator 2 Filament Guide Tube (Teflon 6.0mm OD / 4.0mm ID / 50cm - 52cm long)
(2) A 10mm piece cut from the original 5th Generation Guide Tube Tools:
Drill bits up to 10mm
Reamer and round file Process (Refer to instructions on images):
(1) Remove the drawer from the rear of the machine
(2) Carefully work out location to drill the two holes (Through top of the drawer and up from the spool area so holes are in alignment (Make sure clearance is allowed for moulded support surfaces under the top surface of the drawer). Suggested location measurements are shown in the images provided.
(3) Starting with a small drill (2mm) progressively drill holes in both surfaces out to 6.5mm.
(4) Continue to drill out the hole on the top surface of the drawer until it is a 10mm hole (leave the lower hole into the spool area at 6.5mm). As a suggestion, large drill bits used on a power drill can be very 'aggressive' on thin plastic surfaces so try drilling it out using the drill bit in your hand with a cloth wrapped around it. This will minimise the risk of damage/mistakes.
(5) Clean up holes with a reamer and/or round file until the printed insert slips in easily and turns freely.
(6) Attach the printed circlip as a retainer so the inserted piece cannot lift out.
(7) Place the piece (10mm) of 5th Generation Guide Tube cut from the original guide tube into the top of the Smart Extruder. This will help ensure the filament is correctly aligned as it enters the top of the Smart Extruder.
(8) Place the printed extra cap onto the top of the Smart Extruder (Refer images)
(9) Reinstall the drawer with a spool of filament.
(10) Install Replicator 2 (50cm) or slightly longer (52cm ideal) Teflon guide tube from rear insert onto the new Smart Extruder cap.
(11) Load filament and print.... Note: The larger diameter, shorter length and more direct route of the replacement filament guide tube should minimise resistance of filament feeding. The tube needs to be PTFE/Teflon with a 6mm Outside Diameter / 4mm Inside Diameter / min. 50cm length.

comments.text: I assume you have only recently purchased your 5th Gen Replicator and it came with a Smart Extruder+. The new Smart Extruder+ manages filament feed better than the original extruder. However, if you want freer running filament and a shorter feed path you may still want to do this modification.

comments.author: dcperdue

comments.text: YOU ARE A GOD! Thank you!!! Been looking for a good way to change the tube!
comments.author: AOcolossus

comments.text: The standard guide tube holder has a 2.25mm inside diameter... the Replicator 2 is 4.0mm so almost double the size. This greatly reduces internal friction as the filament barely touches the sides whereas with the standard tube, based on the friction, there is clearly a lot of contact. Yes you could run it without any tube but this is neater and gives the filament a 'supported/guided' path into the extruder.

description.text: The Dewalt 611 is a great router to use as the spindle for CNC machines, but it does have one drawback: the motor is air cooled, and this air is vented out the bottom of the motor housing. This blows all the chips and dust into the environment, making everything a big mess. I've designed this plate to screw into the bottom of the router, deflecting the air upwards and away from the spindle. I've also added an optional mounting for a vacuum hose with a footprint that can accommodate a removable, magnetized dust shoe. You can either print just the deflector plate, or you can print the deflector plate with the vacuum coupling and the dust shoe. You can customize the SCAD code to tweak the model to your needs. The SCAD is somewhat difficult to manipulate because it is generated by Python code. The Python code can be found at my GitHub repository.

In order to attach the deflector plate, you will will need the following items:
  • 20mm M4 Socket Cap Screws (x2)
  • M4 close ended tap (x1)
    • Steps:

  • Remove the two tapping screws from the bottom of your router.

  • Remove the yellow arrestor button and its housing from the side of the router.

  • Using the preexisting screw holes on the button housing, carefully re-tap the holes with an M4 tap. Ideally, you will have a closed-ended tap, but you can also get away with using a through hole tap. Just make sure not to drive the tap too far, or else you will puncture the plastic button housing.

  • Position the deflector plate against the base of the router, inserting the screw posts into the recessed holes on the bottom.

  • Install the arrestor button and its housing into the router, and use two 20MM M4 socket caps screws to secure the deflector to the router base.
    • If you want to use the dust shoe, follow the same instructions above. You will need a few more things to complete the build.
  • Neodymium Disc Magnets - 1/4" x 1/16" (x8)
  • Epoxy (x1)
  • Strip Brush or Foam (x1)
    • Steps:

  • The channel in the dust shoe is 7.5mm wide. If you need the channel wider, you will need to edit the Python or SCAD code to your specifications. You can also adjust the diameter and depth of your magnets.

  • Once you print the deflector mount and dust shoe, apply glue into the eight magnet holes and insert your magnets. Make sure you attach the magnets with opposing poles (for example, all North facing magnets in the deflector mount, and all South facing magnets in your dust shoe). Let the glue cure.

  • Slowly glue in your brush strip, adding glue as you insert the brush. Let the glue cure.

title: Football Kicker Toy

description.text:
In celebration of the Patriots winning Super Bowl XLIX, and their fourth ever Super Bowl victory, Your Wild World is happy to release the football kicker toy! After a few hours of printing, and a little prep work, this cool DIY toy snaps right together. Now you can rain down footballs of doom on your opponents and foes just like the Patriots!  
You also might notice the deflated appearance of the football. This is for ideal handling characteristics. If we were the Patriots, we could win with a ball full of sand, but we're not.

Although these pieces need very little support and will probably print fine without support, we recommend it. It's easier to clean support out of the connector holes than droopy strings of plastic.   
All pieces can be printed at 10%infill with 2 shells.   
The finger_set.stl files, the connector_set.stl files, and the little_football.stl files are the ones where support may be helpful. None of the other files should need support.   
If a raft helps keep your prints flat, then it might be a good idea for the rail_set.stl files.

A fabric-based portable XY gantry. The two driving ideas behind the design are the way in which the string is wound in order to achieve two degrees of freedom, and the notion of 3D printing components with eyelets so that they can be sewn onto fabric. The components were printed on a Dimension FDM machine with support material. Some post-processing was necessary to enlarge holes for bearing shafts and bearings. I'd imagine that you could print on a Makerbot and still get a useable component after additional post-print work. I'm using surplus gearhead motors which I found on ebay, but stepper motors could be easily adapted by changing the drive holder. Additional information and media regarding the project can be found here: http://newtextiles.media.mit.edu/?p=570

description.text:
Faux stained glass-light catcher.
Frame prints upright, "glass" pieces print upside down. Flip "glass" pieces over and glue into recesses in upright frame. Printed in ABS at .3mm on Solidoodle Press. Model is scaled for 8" x 8" platform. Use white glue or Acetone to glue pieces into frame. See instructions for printing glass with pattern inside...

Patterns in glass are achieved by selecting honeycomb infill, I used various sizes, but 20% works well. Profile for printing glass is as follows.
1 bottom, 1 top, 20% honeycomb infill. At .3mm the glass will be 6 slices thick, with honeycomb infill. Frame was printed 2 tops, 2 bottoms and 20% infill. Print the fish.stl twice, in different colors to achieve the multicolor effect. Place half in place in both fish, then print another color and place the remainder, and put into place. Sounds complicated, but one at a time is not too much of a brain twister.

title: Customizable Mini Hotend Fan Duct (Makerfarm i3/i3v compatible)

description.text:
Since the X carriage hides the top portion on any hotend on the Makerfarm i3/i3v, cooling a small hotend (like J-head MkV or Aluhotend) can be difficult, since most fan ducts are too large and get too close to the heating block. This fan duct/mount has a slight inclination, so it will no t come too close to the heating block.  
The SCAD model is parametric, so you should easily be able to configure the fan duct to your needs. By default it is configured to use a 25mm fan, but can easily be changed to accomodate larger fans.
I printed my fan duct using 2 perimeters and 30% infill.

title: Spinning Toy, Dolphins
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: My rendition of yet another very old, and very simple, children's toy. Sure there is the possibility of potential, kinetic and mass inertia energy involved (try it with just the axle), and as such there most certainly must be some sort of physics lesson that can be derived from somewhere in this thing, but most important, the grandkids love it, which of course is why I made it. Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5gkM4ybjZo4. Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill).

Parts I purchased:  
1) 1 4" by 8" sheet of 200 grit sandpaper (hobby, craft or hardware store).  
2) 1/2" wide double sided tape (hobby, craft or hardware store).  
Study "Assembly.skp".  
Print and assemble all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp". Carefully remove the hold down pads on "Base.stl" and "Axle.stl".  
Place a strip of sticky tape on the rolling surface of each of the two ramps.  Next, carefully stick the sheet of sandpaper on the tape, then carefully aligning the edge with the edge of the ramp.  Once positioned and secured in place, carefully trim the excess away using a razor blade or hobby knife.  Repeat for the remaining ramp.  I've included a photo of a completed ramp.  
Comment if you have questions.

description.text:
• Much Much Lighter
  • Easier to assemble
  • Many Fewer screws/nuts/washers
  • No Squashed frog
  • Can be attached/removed without removing the Y rails
  • Easily adaptable and reconfigurable

title: OUYA Game Console Enclosure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: To celebrate the exciting launch of the OUYA open gaming console, the MakerBot Design Team turned the original OUYA enclosure design files into an enclosure that will print well on the MakerBot Replicator 2 Desktop 3D Printer. ThereÃ¢â¬â¢s a case, a lid, and a spring-loaded button. Now what?! Download the .stl files from this page, then print and assemble them according to the instructions below. These are the settings our designers have come up with, but the files are in your hands now. OUYA wants you to have open access to your console, and so do we. You can choose to try out some other settings, and you can even pull the .stl file into your preferred 3D design software and add features. If you want to go further with the design, weÃ¢â¬â¢ve included the .3dm file, too. To read more about OUYA and their mission to make TV console gaming accessible to independent game developers, check out our blog post: http://mbot.co/1x9

All parts were designed and tested using MakerBot PLA Filament, but may print successfully using ABS. Case, Lid, & Spring
Infill: 10%
Shells: 1 shell (total; so 0 extra shells)
Layer height resolution: 0.20-0.25 mm Button (use a translucent color)
Infill: 0%
Shells: 50 (fifty!)
Layer height resolution: 0.3 mm. Turn the active cooling fan ON. Instructions:
Slot the Button into the spring from the smooth side (the side that printed against the build plate), then give the button a quarter turn to lock it in place. Slot the long spring arm into the lid (it will only fit one way) and gently work the other two spring arms into their slots. Make sure you don't bend the spring too far in any direction. Make sure the button can move freely and isn't catching anywhere. Slot the OUYA hardware into the printed case. Align the two forked guides on the inside of the lid with the OUYA board and press the lid onto the case. It should seat with a satisfying snap.

comments.text: I'll just say that this really is a good design.   It printed PERFECTLY in ABS at the recommended settings and much more than that, made the OUYA USABLE!  The metal design of the enclosure was awful for the poorly designed bluetooth controller setup.  Putting it in this case utterly fixed all OUYA controller lag issues I was having.

title: Airbus Flap Panel and Handle with step functionality

description.text:
Note: Does not assemble properly! Was quick proof of concept.

Models

  • As fitted on Airbus A32X/A330/A340/A350/A380 aircraft.

    • Airbus Flaps Panel and Lever for simulation purposes. Includes step functionality to allow it to jump into the five settings (0, 1, 2, 3, FULL). Haven't included any design for position sensing yet. Solutions online appear to use either a variable resistor connected with gears or microswitches to detect which position it is in. Background

  • By increasing the camber (greater lift coefficient CL) and surface area of the wing, the flaps increase lift . Hence, the aircraft can lower its speed for landing, requiring shorter runways.

    • Notes:
  • The long rod is intended to be M4 Aluminium.
  • No provisions (yet) for springback of the stepping mechanism. Could probably done by drilling out a wider hole for spring between know/ step lock piece or adding a rubber band in the lower half.
  • Dimensions are based off tape-measurements in photos. If anybody can compare it to their Airbus to double-check, it would be great ;)
  • Really, I have no clue how smoothly this works. Was a bit of practise and fun in Solidworks. Feedback and such is most welcome.

This water cannon has (besides the lack of a wheel suspension functional parts. The nozzle of the internal water output will be modified, to distort the output of the water and increase the vacuum for the air intake.  
It's a work in progress, to test some fluid dynamics features of SolidWorks.  
This is not a replica, but a fantasy model of a non excisting thing. Doesn't mean the Water Cannon AIR Special isn't a great toy for kids.

Mind extruded with Autodesk 123D Design
Most of the work was done with profiles / revolve / push / tweak / mirror / copy / paste / boolean. Working with solids was most of the time in one axes, to extrude after a copy / paste / scale action. It's a work in progress, to test some fluid dynamics features of SolidWorks. Why a cannon?
The assigment was to draw a cannon (the noisy kind), but I made a harmless water cannon.

title: Raspberry Pi Game Boy Horizontal Layout for Model B+ and Model A+

description.text:
I always wondered what a horizontal Game Boy would play like and thanks to the Adafruit Game Grrl http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:382485 now I can find out! I am trying to fit everything in the original footprint so I'm excluding a speaker. Unlike the original Pi Grrl, this is made for the new Rapberry Pi Model B+, Model A+ and Raspberry Pi 2 Model B. The new Pi's won't fit in the old Pi Grrl with the Adafruit PiTFT 2.8" LCDs. So far everything fits in this configuration, though! I am waiting on the battery, powerboost 500, micro lipo charger and game controller to finish this build. More updates to come! Problems With current .stl files:
[2/3/15]
-No holes for screws to hold case together. Easily fixed with a drill but I'll fix the .stl files
-Power switch needs to be changed. It interferes with the placement of the Pi B+
-Mounting an audio jack at the top will be tricky at best.
-Yeah I put the USB for the charger where your left palm sits.
-The holes for the buttons are slightly too small I will update the files as I find and fix problems.

This uses the internals from Adafruit's Raspberry Pi Gameboy http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:382485 except I'm using a Model B+ instead of the Model A. I've excluded standouts for the Pi initially so that you can mount the Pi with double-sided foam tape. Also this leaves you room to fit whichever Pi you have without having to remix the design. I used an old Rev 1 Model A Pi on my Gameboy Pi build and ended up mounting it with tape anyway. I left screw holes for the Powerboost 500 and Micro-Lipo charger since I wasn't comfortable using tape to mount them on my Pi Game Boy build. There is no access to the MicroSD card from the outside of the case so make sure to download the full NES library before sealing up your build. I did this on purpose so that I could have a nice, sealed box. I will probably change this later but it seemed like a good idea at the time. I will update as I make progress on this build.

Works in Customizer! Updated to tweak nut capture size on 5 Feb 2015. A modifiable, parameterized knob useful for making knobs with hex head attachments. I tried to fully parameterize the design to make modification easy. By default, it will make a 5-pointed knob for a 1/4" bolt. If you want to change it, you can set:
  • the number of points on the finger knob
  • the diameter of the knob
  • the height of the knob
  • the diameter of the thru-bolt for the shaft (in mm)
  • optional nut captures on top and bottom (in Open SCAD Only)
    • Thanks! to 'fastryan' for sharing the knob he designed - this was the basis for my code. If this isn't versatile enough for you, check out wstein's Ultimate Nut Knob Generator: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:713300 @billgertz successfully used these knobs with the hold down part here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:752098

comments.text: what does parameterized mean?

comments.text: Parameterized means that parameters control most aspects of the design: rather than a single knob, you can tweak the parameters and make any of dozens (hundreds?) of different knobs to meet your needs.  Diameter, height, number of "fingers" on the knob, etc. can all be adjusted quickly and easily.

comments.text: Perhaps it might be better to put the Y motor on the other side of Z rods to help counterbalance the significant cantilever you have on that axis. Also, having the Z rods aligned in the X direction as you've done doesn't help support the cantilever -- I assume that's why Printrbot has theirs aligned along the Y. You could rotate the Z rods' arrangement 45 degrees (so it's like neither a Printrbot nor a SmartRap, but rather between the two) without changing your design too much, and it would give more sturdy support to the Y axis.

title: Mini Quad Flight Deck for FPV Spanky Frame

description.text:
This is an add on flight deck for a mini quad frame, it has the mounts for the Spanky frame.  There are two versions of the main piece, one has slots for rubber mounts for Flight controller and other one has the normal 30mm mount holes.  
Also there is the FPC board mount it uses a 9 gram servo to tilt the camera.  
The area between the camera and the flight controller mount has to rails systems.  One fits the minim OSD board and the other is for a bluetooth board.  Also there is a small hole on the side to fit a switch 4mm x 9mm they sell them at RadioShack, had one that came in an Arduino kit.  I use the switch to on the receive wire to switch between the OSD and the Bluetooth.

comments.text: I adjusted the screw mounts for top deck to align better to the original top deck plate.  One frame I have the screw holes are slightly different than the other one, so adjusted the mount holes on here to be a happy medium between the slight variations in frames I have.  Guessing two different batches of Spanky frames.

title: Pyramid Elbows & Topper, 1/2 Inch PVC Pipe Fitting Series #HalfInchPVCFittings

description.text: A friend requested fittings to make a pyramid topper for a pvc cube, so I made these. They are designed to work with my series of 1/2" PVC fittings. You can build a box with a pyramid top by using the 3-way elbow for the bottom joints (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:533492) and these pyramid elbows and topper for the top joints. The angle is 45 degrees, so it is scalable to any pvc length AS LONG AS YOUR HORIZONTAL AND DIAGONAL PIPES ARE OF EQUAL LENGTH. I will continue to add new fittings to the series and share them as a derivative of my original 3-Way Elbow. I am not currently able to respond to requests to make these in different angles, but you are welcome to make your own using the provided Sketchup files. Please tag your new creations with #HalfInchPVCFittings.

title: tripod mount pistol shelf with integrated 1/4-20 nuts

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gCI1UdT3eRY Pistol shelf / gun rest to be mounted on a tripod. Combine with gun yoke http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:656310
a 1/4-20 threaded rod, and (4) 1/4-20 nuts to create a stable aiming platform for your hand cannon! Similar to shooting sticks for your rifle, but with a shelf to rest the grip of the handgun as well.

Pause your printer just before the hex nut cavities are covered, insert 1/4-20 nuts, and continue printing. (This was at the end of layer 44 of 47 on my print) Screw a threaded rod approximately 4 inches into the end of the pistol shelf, then a jam nut. This jam nut will lock the rod in place at the desired height. Screw on a second jam nut about 1/2 an inch down the threaded rod. Screw on the gun yoke with integrated nut on top of the threaded rod. Use the jam nut to secure the yoke in place in the proper orientation. The final height can be adjusted at any time depending on the size of your firearm and in what manner you want to level it on the shelf.
Simply loosen the jam nuts and rotate the entire assembly to the desired height and re-tighten. Affix the whole assembly on a tripod to complete the pistol shelf. Made on a Printrbot Simple Metal in HIPS using 0.2mm layer height. PLEASE NOTE: This device is only to help steady your aim. It will NOT hold the firearm for you, and will certainly NOT ABSORB RECOIL. YOU are still responsible for controlling the firearm at all times.

author: Muhalo

description.text:
These replace the clips that hold the filament guide tubes on the rear of the FlashForge Creator 3D Pro and perhaps other models and brands of printers.  
You can use these to either replace broken factory clips or to upgrade the factory clips.  
No more breaking your fingernails or having to use a tool to unclip the tube, simply push the guide tube on these clips to hold the tube firmly in place or pop the tube off when changing the filament.  
These also hold the guide tube further out from the back of the printer and closer to the center of the filament spool preventing the filament from getting caught behind the spools.
I had success with 25% infill using PLA without support and without a raft.

Here's a 3D printed mini quad based on my popular tricopter design. It shares many of the same design features, but with more internal space and the ability to carry a larger battery. It's still 250 size, and the arms from the tricopter can be used to extend it if desired. Reccomended components: SunnySky 2204 2300kV motors
Gemfan 5x3 Props
12A ESCs with SimonK
3S 1300mah - 1500mah Battery
Naze32 Flight Controller
PZ0420M FPV Camera
HobbyKing TS5823 Mini Video Transmitter
8x M3x14mm screws for the body/arm connections
2x M3x8mm screws for the battery cover
As with the tri, I sell kits for those without 3D printers. Enjoy!

Recommended print settings: Layer height: 0.2mm
Number of Perimeters: 2
Bottom Solid Layers: 3
Top Solid Layers: 3
Infill: 20%
I usually print in PLA for better inter-layer adhesion and more rigidity, but ABS should be fine as well.

author: LilEffects

description.text:
Wanted to test this type of dampener so I designed one that is very similar to the Astrosyn.  Print the motor and mounting plates from a hard material and print the dampener out of something flexible.  You can adjust settings on the dampener like perimeters and infill to change the dampening effect.  
Glue together after parts are finished, I used a stepper to make sure all the holes were aligned.  First tried contact cement but had to redo it and super glue ended up working better.  Total dampener should be 6mm thick when assembled.

description.text:
Makes round or square buttons with round or square shaft holes.
Adges can be rounded and beveled. Square holes are keyholed to prevent rounding of internal corners
Tops of holes are vaulted so no support will be needed inside them. Default is to make replacement buttons for Atlas stove
Button is a 10mm round button press fit onto a square 3.3mm shaft
this is a standard size for "isostat" switches

Print fairly fine as internal hole is small. I printed 0.25mm.
Print top up, as vaulting (45deg) of holes means no support will be used inside. HoleOS parameter allows you to trim the internal size of shaft holes. My UP printer tends to make holes too small, so this is eg 0.3mm for round holes. Oddly square holes needed 0.0
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1BYWR7lpcFR

From the 1960s classic Gerry Anderson series. Based on a model by Hans De Ridder at http://grabcad.com/library/thunderbird1. I split it into several pieces to improve printability. I printed this with supports, assembled with superglue, and painted with acrylics. 2016/1/26 Update: The main body and wings have been smoothed and optimized for printing. An alternate version with built-in support is also provided.

I've printed this twice, once at 100% size, 10% infill, and once at 60% size, 0% infill. Both worked well when sliced with Makerware and printed on a Replicator 2 in PLA.
  • TB1-Improved.stl requires Support; raft is optional.
  • TB1-Alternate+Support.stl should be printed with raft enabled. No extra support is required.
    • The wings can be made to pivot by drilling a 1.75mm hole in each wing housing, then inserting a small piece of filament through the hole in the wing.

title: ATX Power supply quick lab connector REMIXED

description.text:
Sometimes , there is no power supply and need only thing with the hand is old psu atx . With this small box are now practical to use somewhere else all atx 1.0 compatible power source . description.text: Akisbot is the Akismet mascot; he was originally designed by Dan Hauk, but I'm responsible for the 3D version. I designed the entire thing in OpenSCAD; the Akisbot.scad script has all of the modules necessary to build the robot; the printed Akisbot in the pictures was printed at 40% scale.

Print one of each STL, plus an additional antenna, bicep, forearm, eyeball, eye ring, tread brace, tread crawler, and three tread wheels.  Assemble, glue, and enjoy.  
The tread crawlers should be printed with the "Only print perimeters" setting to get the flexible tread that will fit over the wheels.  
You may need to play around with sizing of the joints in order to get them to fit properly, depending on your specific printer.

This is a noteholder I designed up for fun. Be sure to make sure your retractions and bridges are ideal... this thing takes a while to clean up with an exacto blade..... I hit this one with a butane torch, which is what it's singed in places. Otherwise it works. The last image that's midprint is actually the same holder... yeah there was a lot of cleanup... TEST those retractions BEFORE hand...

• Nozzle: 0.35mm
  • Layer Thickness: 0.2mm
  • Perimeter #: 2
  • Top Surfaces: 4
  • Bottom Surfaces: 3
  • Infill: Lines, 10%
  • Nozzle Temp: 225C
  • Bed Temp: 60C
  • Print Speed: no more than 60mm/s (I've included my settings in teh files)
    • I included teh MatterControl settings file I used. Keep in mind, I had "retraction" and "bridging" issues on my initial print, so be sure to play with these settings prior to printing this.

comments.text: I am thinking about putting a Chimera to put onto my rigidbot regular dingle extruder.  I currently am using a v6 with your other underdog mount and i have a few questions.  What electronics board are you using to control your extruder motors, fan, thermistor, and heater cartridge?  Where would I buy it?  Also are you having any problems with the bearings staying put in the mount or do they fit pretty snugly?  Is there a fan duct that you suggest to use with this design or are you designing one?  Thanks so much.
comments.author: andrewb1999

comments.text: The controller I am using is the stock IAP controller, It handles it all just fine. The bearings fit snuggly and do not have any issues popping off or anything. They snap on and off easily and seem very secure.
comments.author: andrewb1999

comments.text: How do you connect 2 extruders to the board that normally sits ontop of the extruder motor?  Do you have the dual extruder version?
comments.author: Sactocal

comments.text: Ahh, I mis-understood, sorry. I created a second custom ribbon cable to bypass the little extruder PCB entirely. I just wired from the main controller directly out with plugs that individually connect to the thermistor/heater/fan/motor.
comments.author: andrewb1999

comments.text: Oh okay that makes sense.  Could you possibly post a guide about how to do that on the google+ group or on the wiki?  Thanks again.

My BBQ had too few pegs and they didn't have enough of a lip to keep the tools from falling off as I moved the BBQ. So I came up with this to give me enough space for my tool and tall enough so they don't slip off. It fits onto the existing pegs. The picture shows my BBQ so if you have the same one, this will work. Otherwise I've included Inventor files for what it's worth.
No special requirements for making this. I made sure it fit on a 200mm x 200mm bed. Looks like it comes in as inches. Scale by 25.4 to make it come out right.

title: Soap Dish / Tray with great water drainage

description.text: 3'' by 4'' Soap dish for your shower or Tub. It has a lip around the top to keep soap from sliding out of it and has slots for water drainage. On the bottom at the corners it has raised feet to allow water to run back into the shower/tub . After searching thingiverse I didnt find one to fullfill all these requirements so I made one. double sided sticky tape could be applied to the feet and trimmed if needed to mount on an angle . Hope someone can use this.
print feet side down using low or medium supports, I used 25 percent infill and thick shell. up to you.
